lessons.title: Welcome to CS102
masteryOutcomes: Understand what data structures and algorithms are about
Learn how the course progresses across units

lessons.title: What Is a Data Structure?
masteryOutcomes: Explain the purpose of data structures for organizing and managing data
Describe why different data structures are necessary

lessons.title: Index-Based Data Structures
masteryOutcomes: Understand how positions map to stored values

lessons.title: ðŸ“š Theory Practice Lesson: Data structures foundations
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Demonstrate understanding of what data structures are, why different ones exist, and how index-based access works conceptually.

lessons.title: Understanding Arrays
masteryOutcomes: Identify arrays as ordered collections with fixed positions

lessons.title: Accessing Elements in Arrays
masteryOutcomes: Explain how indices map to element locations
Validate index boundaries and detect out-of-range access
Add new elements to an existing array

lessons.title: Updating and Replacing Array Values
masteryOutcomes: Replace first, middle, and last elements
Evaluate the effect of in-place updates

lessons.title: âš™ Practice Lesson: Study planner array
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply array concepts to create, access, and update a list of planned study sessions using index-based operations. Output: A simple script that creates an array of study tasks, safely accesses elements by index, updates specific positions, and prints the final updated plan.

lessons.title: Removing Elements from Arrays
masteryOutcomes: Predict how removal affects index positions

lessons.title: Challenge: Basic Array Operations
masteryOutcomes: Demonstrate understanding of basic array manipulation

lessons.title: Combined Array Operations in Sequence
masteryOutcomes: Execute access, update, and remove operations in order
Return multiple values from array manipulation

lessons.title: âš™ Practice Lesson: Media playlist manager
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use combined array operations to access, update, remove, and return elements in sequence within a playlist-like structure. Output: A script that manages a playlist array by updating tracks, popping/removing items, and printing both removed tracks and the final playlist state.

lessons.title: Using Arrays for Structured Problem Solving
masteryOutcomes: Break problems into steps using array operations

lessons.title: Introducing High-Dimensional Arrays
masteryOutcomes: Identify real-world use cases for nested data

lessons.title: Implementing High-Dimensional Arrays in Python
masteryOutcomes: Create and access nested lists using multiple indices

lessons.title: âš™ Practice Lesson: Weekly habit tracker grid

Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Identify when a stack is empty

Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

lessons.title: âš™ Practice Lesson: Customer service queue
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.

masteryOutcomes: Choose between stacks and queues in scenarios
Simulate combined stack and queue behavior

lessons.title: âš™ Practice Lesson: Task processor with stacks and queues
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Implement a queue using `collections.deque` and combine it with a list-based stack to decide when to process tasks in FIFO vs LIFO order. Output: A Python script that accepts a small set of predefined tasks, routes them through either a queue or a stack, then prints the order in which tasks are processed under each strategy.

lessons.title: âš™ Practice Lesson: Search helper for movie watchlist
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply linear and binary search to different list types and justify which is appropriate based on data size and ordering. Output: A small program that lets a user search for movies in an unsorted and a sorted watchlist and reports whether the movie was found and how many steps each search took.

lessons.title: âš™ Practice Lesson: Sorting student scores with bubble and insertion sort
